Linear Regression Part 3: Code

Below is the link of a very basic linear regression code using Skelarn and taken R2 as metric 

https://lnkd.in/g_j5rSn 

Steps are quite simple:
1.    split the dataset using sklearn train_test_split.
a.     (X_Train, Y_Train) : use this to fit the model
b.    X_Test : use this to predict the values
c.     Y_Test : Do not touch it until you are measuring the accuracy stage
2.    Metric chosen : R2Score because it is one of the best metric from Regression analysis.If the R2Score value is closer to 1 then the model is better because the Sum of the squares of the Residual are almost equal to the Sum of the square of the Total.

In Linear Regression the goal is to find the Best-Fit line which fits both the training and test data as well as possible, if we have only one dependent variable then the Best-Fit line will be a line, if we have more than one dependent variable the it will be a plane or hyperplane.
The Best-Fit line is a line or plane or hyper plane which minimizes the errors in each of the data-points in train and test.
Error for a given data point is calculated as (actual values ‚Äì predicted value) but the problem with this equation is if the actual data-point is below the best-fit line then the error will be negative and for vice versa it will be positive, so while summing it may cancel out other errors, so we calculate the square of errors, and we try to minimize the square of the errors.

When talking data science, data is the first thing that should come up. We'll be working upon and investing entire time on it. Here are some traits about data.
1) Structured or Unstructured - Structured data is well represented into a fix schema eg. databases, excels etc. Working on it is easier as it makes more comprehensible. Unstructured data has no specific form, from a file on the drive to a physical document anything . It is converted into structured format first.
2)Quantitative and Categorical - Quantitative data is a measurable value telling the degree of a object. Categorical data tells about a properties, it can't be measured. It is a good practice to encode such data into numeric representations.
3)Big or Little - This is in terms with scale of data, usually the larger data we obtain better it is as it has less chances of missing any case. It can also be sampled to a smaller data set if required. A small data set on the other hand takes less time to analyse, takes less computing resources and easier to perform. Scale of data should be controlled problem to problem, for example if analysing voters mood in a constituency one can use a poll of 100-500 individuals rather than going on Social media and analyse all the posts and trends.

Here is my summary about the project :-
1. There was a class imbalance(1.68:1) which was dealt with by Oversampling the minority class (by generating synthetic examples in the train set) using the SMOTE class from imblearn Library
2. I used the SVM algorithm as there were only 500 examples to work on.
3. I used the Radial Basis Function(RBF) kernel for my SVM to make my decision-boundary curved.
4. I selected those feature that provided me with the highest accuracy (F1 score in this case) using the mlxtend library.
5. The Receiver Operating Curve (ROC) was used to visualize the problem. It tells how much the model is capable of distinguishing between classes.The closer the curve comes to the 45-deg diagonal of the ROC space, the less accurate the model is. Scikit_plot library was used for plotting the same.
